verb.description: Deform, pulverize, or force inwards by compressing forcefully.
examples: you can crush a pill between two spoons
he was crushed to death by a subway train

verb.description: (of a government or state) violently subdue (opposition or a rebellion)
examples: the government had taken elaborate precautions to crush any resistance

verb.description: Bring about a feeling of overwhelming disappointment or embarrassment in (someone)
examples: his defeat crushed a lot of left-wing supporters

verb.description: Have a brief but intense infatuation for (someone)
examples: the girl I had been crushing on sat next to me

noun.description: A crowd of people pressed closely together, especially in an enclosed space.
examples: a number of youngsters fainted in the crush

noun.description: A brief but intense infatuation for someone, especially someone unattainable or inappropriate.
examples: she did have a crush on Dr. Russell

noun.description: A drink made from the juice of pressed fruit.

origin: Middle English: from Old French cruissir, gnash (teeth) or crack, of unknown origin.
